results.title: Accident
results.creator_credit: Tom Daly, ONF | NFB, Martin Duckworth and Pat Crawley
results.brief_description: The subject is the actual crash of a small plane in which one man survived to tell the story. What he describes is his view of the world now, after being on the edge of death. It is, he says, like being continually stoned - neutral but more fully aware, accepting life without bias, a condition he feels we are all coming to. Award: New York.

results.title: Accessible city doctor Wilfred Owen
results.brief_description: Cities are growing at a calamitous pace and they will be unliveable unless the idea of accidental growth is abandoned in favour of planning. Dr. Wilfred Owen discusses some of the features essential to the functioning of a city for business by day and recreation by night, and the role of transportation in effecting the growth of cities for the benefit of people

results.title: Access: experiment in Port Adelaide
results.brief_description: Patterned on the Canadian “Challenge for Change” experiments, this is an example of the video access concept at work for the Department of Social Security, helping to cut down the often mythical barriers between citizens and Government Departments involved in social welfare. No other credits available.

results.title: Access Video 1973-1982
results.creator_credit: Helen Eisler and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
This is a retrospective look at Access Video, an
independent public broadcasting project, using archival
footage shot over a period of nine years Australia wide.The images encapsulate Australian life on a social,
political and cultural level providing a historical glimpse
of the developing community and political activity during
the seventies whilst also illustrating the growth and
maturing of independent video within Australia. NB: Some
footage is of poor quality both in sound and image.

results.title: Access to the future
results.creator_credit: Mornington School Support Centre and Chris O'Rourke
results.brief_description: Teacher librarians in primary schools face a varied demand on services and resources. This program demonstrates the basic approaches in establishing both policy and resources. Aspects of catalogues and cooperative curriculum planning are discussed, drawing upon practical experiences of some Victorian schools. Suitable for school councils and parent presentations.

results.title: Access News greatest hits 2000. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, Campbell Manderson and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
This compilation showcases the best stories from SKA TV’s “Access News” broadcasts on Channel 31 in the year 2000. SKA TV’s “Access news” is a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994. Shedding light on perspectives or issues otherwise not seen, stories range from front-line coverage of anti-globalisation protests to satirical critiques of commercial media. “Greatest hits 2000” is a compilation of 15 of “Access news’” best stories from the year 2000.
Highlights from part 1: “Violence is violence”: hundreds of Sydney residents take over the streets to protest car-dominated public space and offer a vision of urban sustainability. Their celebration is met with a brutal police response. “Fire water earth”: the world’s largest uranium mine is located at Roxby Downs in South Australia. It is owned by multinational mining corporation WMC and is built on Arabunna and Kokotha land. This story follows the nuclear trail from an occupation of a WMC borefield by Arabunna elder Kevin Buzzacott and his supporters to a daring mission by videoactivists into the heart of WMC headquarters in Melbourne, surprising the boss himself.
Highlights from part 2: “Fortress Goolengook”: after having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge) to ensure their safety against further attacks. “Viva Falantil”: a tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation. “Herald Sun occupation”: during the World Economic Forum (WEF) held in Melbourne in September 2000, a group of protesters went to the Herald Sun newspaper to voice their concern over the paper’s exceptionally biased coverage of the protests outside the WEF.

results.title: Access News greatest hits 2000. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description:
Access News Greatest Hits 2000 (Part 2 of 2)
SKA TV’s Access News is a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
Giving light to perspectives or issues otherwise not seen, stories range from front-line coverage of anti-globalisation protests to satirical critiques of commercial media.
‘Greatest Hits 2000’ is a compilation of 15 of Access News’s best stories from the year 2000.
Highlights from part 2:
Fortress Goolengook : After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks.
Viva Falantil : A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation.
Herald Sun Occupation : During the World Economic Forum (WEF) held in Melbourne in September 2000, a group of protesters went to the Herald Sun newspaper to voice their concern the paper’s exceptionally biased coverage of the protests outside the WEF.

results.title: Acceptable Levels
results.brief_description: John Davies’ incisive drama on the responsibility of the media to those they film and photograph and the abuse of that responsibility in the pursuit of “acceptable” news and entertainment. A drama set in Northern Ireland.

results.title: Accent on learning
results.creator_credit: Department of Photography, Ohio State University and Robert W Wagner
results.brief_description: This film explores the meaning of teaching and suggests creative methods for use by teachers. Samples of teaching methods are shown: lecturers who communicate with words, with the assistance of the blackboard, with slide projectors etc. Success in teaching rests upon organisation of material in a meaningful way. Suggested materials are charts, films, film strips, lantern slides, tape recorders.
